document.docAuthor: Schönberg, Christine Hanna Lydia & Grass, Stefanie & Heiermann, Anke Tarja
document.docTitle: Cliona minuscula, sp. nov. (Hadromerida: Clionaidae) and other bioeroding sponges that only contain tylostyles

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Cliona minuscula, sp. nov. (Hadromerida: Clionaidae) and other bioeroding sponges that only contain tylostyles

docTitle.emphasis:
Cliona minuscula
, sp. nov. ( Hadromerida : Clionaidae ) and other bioeroding sponges that only contain tylostyles

subSection.paragraph: CHRISTINE HANNA LYDIA SCHÖNBERG 1 , STEFANIE GRASS 2 &

ANKE TARJA HEIERMANN
2

paragraph.emphasis: Centre for Marine Studies, The University of Queensland, Brisbane, St. Lucia , QLD 4072 , Australia ;

present address: Carl von Ossietzky Universität Oldenburg, Fakultät 5 , Institut für Biologie und Umweltwissenschaften, Abteilung Zoomorphologie und Systematik, 26111 Oldenburg, ph + 49 ­(0) 441­7983611 , fax + 49 ­ (0) 441­7983250 . E­mail christine.schoenberg@uni­oldenburg.de

Carl von Ossietzky Universität Oldenburg, Fakultät 5 , Institut für Biologie und Umweltwissenschaften, Abteilung Zoomorphologie und Systematik, 26111 Oldenburg, ph + 49 ­(0) 441­7983611 , fax + 49 ­(0) 441­7983250 . E­mail stefanie_grass@web.de, anke@heiermann­family.de

subSection.paragraph:
A new bioeroding sponge belonging to the genus
Cliona
is described from the Australian Great Barrier Reef,
Cliona minuscula ,
sp. nov.
As the sponge lacked microscleres, comparison with existing clionaid species was difficult. We considered 15 other species of
Cliona
with only tylostyles:
C. alderi , C. arenosa . C. caesia
nov. comb.,
C. californiana , C. celata , C. delitrix , C. dissimilis , C. ecaudis , C. insidiosa
,
C. janitrix
,
C. kempi
,
C. laticavicola , C. macgeachii , C. millepunctata
and
C. peponaca .
Characters of all species are presented in table­form to facilitate comparison during future studies. We listed additional species of
Cliona
that were not directly compared to the new species, because they were either invalid, insufficiently described, or they may not be obligate bioeroders. The form and dimensions of the megascleres of
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
indicated that it is distinct from all considered species. Its mean tylostyle dimensions were 225.3 µm length, 4.5 µm shaft width and 6.8 µm tyle width, which is comparatively small. Because other morphological features were small as well (erosion chambers, papillar diameter), this species was named
C. minuscula
. The species record for sponges of the genus
Cliona
reported from Australia is now 11 .

Key words:
Cliona minuscula
, Porifera, new species, description, taxonomy, faunistics

Despite the obvious ecological importance of bioeroding sponges, there is a lack of information about their natural distribution patterns and of comprehensive, detailed descriptions of some uncommon species. These sponges tend to be overlooked during ecological studies due to their cryptic lifestyle, and their exposed parts often match background colours. Determining the taxonomic relationships of bioeroding sponges is difficult, because some species have poor species­specific characters. Classic descriptive procedures are based on skeletal and tissue characters that can change under different ambient conditions (e.g.
Uriz et al. 2003
). Bioeroding sponges display an additional set of characters termed erosion traces, but they can also vary with different conditions (
Borchiellini et al. 2004
,
Calcinai et al. 2004
,
Schönberg 2002 a
and
2003
). As a consequence, similar species of bioeroding sponges have been grouped into speciescomplexes (
Schönberg 2002 b and references therein
), a compromise that hampers studies at the level of individual species.

Bioeroding sponge species have been described to different degrees of quality and quantity. They are comparatively understudied in the Pacific Ocean (
Rosell & Uriz 1997
). This is especially true for small bioeroding sponges that lack distinctive species characters and only occur in ­form (cryptic­papillate). The present study reports the finding of one such species on the Australian Great Barrier Reef. It contains only tylostyles as spicular elements and is here described as a new species. Together with previous records (see
Hooper & Wiedenmayer 1994
,
Wesche et al . 1997
,
Schönberg
2000
and
2001
,
Fromont et al . 2005
), the newly described species brings the record of bioeroding sponges of the genus
Cliona
from Australia to 11 species. Furthermore, we list all previously described bioeroding sponges with only tylostyles as their spicules, stating their validity, presenting their taxonomic characters for comparison, and thus provide a comprehensive checklist of these species and synoptic information for future revisions.

Sponge tissue was obtained during a survey in
October 2003
on SCUBA in the southern corner of Little Pioneer Bay, Orpheus Island, Central Great Barrier Reef (
Fig. 1
). Two specimens of the sample series could not be identified to species level, but they were obviously conspecific. The specimens were kept at ­ 10 ° C, later transferred to 70 % ethanol for long­term storage; vouchers are deposited at the Queensland Museum in Brisbane, Australia (QM). The material was studied following standard procedures (
Schönberg 2000
). Spicule and tissue preparations were processed several times, but tissue was very delicate and difficult to pluck from the minute erosion chambers. Scanning electron micrographs of spicules were obtained at the SEM unit at the Queensland Museum in Brisbane (Hitachi S­ 530 ). Photographs of the morphology of the sponges were taken with a stereoscope (Olympus SZX 9 ) equipped with a photographic unit (Nikon Coolpix 4500 ). In addition, drawings of spicules were made from observations with a light microscope (Olympus BH­ 2 ) and of bioerosion chambers with a dissecting stereoscope (Wild Heerbrugg), both with camera lucida. To verify that the specimens represented a new species, original descriptions and additional literature for 15 other species were consulted. Respective skeletal elements were redrawn and represented to scale with spicules from the present specimens. Available taxonomic characters from all species that were considered were compiled in a table for comparison.

bibRefCitation.author: Grant
bibRefCitation.refString: Grant, R. E. (1826) Notice of a new zoophyte (Cliona celata Gr.) from the Firth of Forth. Edinburgh New Philosophical Journal, 1826, 78 - 81.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Excavating Hadromerida in, and growth form (cryptic­papillate, crypticencrusting and free­living), with tylostyles, styles and\or oxeas and spirasters, raphides, amphiasters and\or microrhabds. Skeleton of the choanosome confused, ectosome in palisade. Original family name Clionidae preoccupied (Gastropoda: Rafinesque 1815 ), amended by
Bouchet and Rützler ( 2003 )
. Synonymies given by
Rützler ( 2002 b)
.

bibRefCitation.author: Grant
bibRefCitation.refString: Grant, R. E. (1826) Notice of a new zoophyte (Cliona celata Gr.) from the Firth of Forth. Edinburgh New Philosophical Journal, 1826, 78 - 81.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Clionaidae in, and growth form, with tylostyles as megascleres; microscleres, if present, spirasters or raphides, which may vary in form. Synonymies given by
Rützler ( 2002 b)
.

Cliona minuscula
,
sp. nov.
holotype : QM G 322595 , wet sample in alcohol, original sample number: 5.46 , 27.10.2003 : in dead, unattached shell of
Tridacna crocea
in 1.0 m depth on reef crest (
Fig. 2
A–B).

Cliona minuscula
,
sp. nov.
paratype : QM G 322596 , slide preparation, entire specimen was used up for the preparation, original sample number: 2.80 , 25.10.2003 : in a dead brain coral in 2.2 m depth, from the reef flat.

Cliona caesia
new comb. , various specimens from Little Pioneer Bay, Orpheus Island, Palm Island Group, Central Great Barrier Reef and Heron Island, Capricorn Bunker Group, Southern Great Barrier Reef Australia , wet samples in alcohol, Queensland Museum, spicule preparations in first author’s collection.

Cliona patera
: MHNG 38767 from the Museum in Geneva, dry specimen, section of a massive sponge. Sample site unknown.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Sample location of
Cliona minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(arrow). HIRS—Heron Island Research Station, LPB—Little Pioneer Bay, PB—Pioneer Bay, QLD—Queensland.

paragraph.emphasis: Description of the holotype QM G 322595

subSubSection.paragraph:
Live ectosome dark brown, endosome lighter brown to beige. Colour fading when frozen or in alcohol, with endosomal tissue becoming almost transparent. Papillae minute, mean papillar diameter 0.44 mm when contracted (minimum = 0.20 mm , maximum = 0.70 mm , SD = 0.14 mm , N = 25 ). Form circular in outline, occasionally irregular. Contracted papilla margins flush with surface, but towards centre ‘sunken’ into substrate, latter forming small circular pits around papillae (
Fig. 2
C–D). Some of these pits in sample QM G 322595 no longer filled with sponge tissue, but with mud and algae. Papillae evenly dispersed, mean distance from each other 0.40 mm (minimum = 0.16 mm , maximum = 0.80 mm , SD = 0.18 mm , N = 25 ), fusion rare. Except for small areas opposite shell umbo, tissue not traversing entire width of shell, but penetrating to a depth of 1–2 mm . Sponge tissue emerging on inner side of shell forming net­like pattern (
Fig. 2
B). External erosion traces on shell outer surface as papillar pits and shallow grooves that connect papillar pits in close vicinity to each other (
Fig. 2
D). Endolithic erosion chambers minute, appearing finely porous, with spherical to oval chambers (
Fig. 2
E–F). Under magnification some chambers more irregular in shape as result of merging (
Fig. 2
F). Mean chamber diameter 0.59 mm (minimum = 0.2 mm , maximum = 1.3 mm , SD = 0.29 , N = 25 ), mean diameter of canals connecting chambers 0.20 mm (minimum = 0.08 mm , maximum = 0.33 mm , SD = 0.07 , N = 10 ).

Endosomal tissue thinly coating chambers and forming fragile membranes. Tylostyles in papillae in loose palisade, spicule points protruding from tissue by about 1 / 3 of spicule length (
Fig. 2
G). Tissue with zooxanthellae (dinoflagellate symbionts) concentrated at the sponge surface (
Fig. 2
H). Endosomal tylostyles aligned in parallel, forming bundles. Bundles in confused orientation. Skeleton comprised of megascleres only, i.e. of tylostyles (
Fig. 3
). Mean tylostyle dimensions comparatively small, with shaft length x shaft width x tyle width: 225.3 x 4.5 x 6.8 µm (
Tab. 1
). Tylostyle width size­frequency distributions skewed to left, indicating very uniform final size. Most tyles oval, slightly elongated (
Fig. 3
A–B), but some round (
Fig. 3
C–D), rarely with secondary swellings. Shafts predominantly straight (
Fig. 3
A–B), neck regions usually subtle, few with sharp creases (
Fig. 3
C–D). Axial threads extending about 2 / 3 into tyles. No vesicles observed when using light microscopy, but occasionally striations in tyles (layering of silica).

Specimen QM G 322595 contains three other species of bioeroding sponges:
Cliona ensifera
,
Cliona cf. orientalis
in ­form and an unidentified species of
Aka
. Latter two species were only tentatively or incompletely identified, as
C. cf. orientalis
lacked microscleres and
Aka
sp. is a small specimen with indistinct fistules.
Aka
sp. and
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
occur in two tiers, with
C. minuscule
,
sp. nov.
forming the upper layer near the shell surface, being traversed by
Aka
sp. papillar canals (
Fig. 2
E–F). The additional species in QM G 322595 are distinct from
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
by their spicules (
Tab. 2
,
Fig. 4
), papillar size (
Tab. 2
,
Fig. 2
A) and form of erosion chambers (
Tab. 2
,
Fig. 2
B, E–F).

To date only two specimens of
Cliona minuscula
,
sp. nov.
have been found, and only from one sample site at Orpheus Island, Palm Island Group, Central Great Barrier Reef.

The species name ‘
minuscula
’ was chosen, as compared to other species of
Cliona ,
the new species has minute papillae and erosion chambers and smaller than average tylostyles.

heading.emphasis:
Remarks on
Cliona minuscula
, sp. nov. and a discussion of a species complex of bioeroding sponges that only contain tylostyles as skeletal elements

subSubSection.paragraph:
The newly described species of a bioeroding sponge from Orpheus Island contains only tylostyles as skeletal elements. The arrangement of spicules and the manner in which the sponge erodes identifies it as a
Cliona
. Comparison with 15 other species of this genus that also contain only tylostyles showed that this sponge has not previously been described (
Tab. 2
). One of the species that we considered was
C. caesia
nov. comb.. Additional samples obtained since the original description support the transfer from
Pione
to
Cliona
. Variable oxeas previously found in
C. caesia
were not present in most of the new samples and are likely to be contaminations or kleptospicula (Schönberg unpublished data). It was also noted that dark bodies in tissue preparations previously described as ‘pigment granules’ (
Schönberg 2000
) are symbiotic dinoflagellates.
C. caesia
thus becomes available for the present comparison.

A number of species have not been considered as they have previously been synonymised with
C. celata
(
Tab. 3
).
Topsent ( 1900 )
further synonymised
C. alderi
and
C. dissimilis
with
C. celata
, however, these two species are presently regarded as valid (
Rützler & Stone 1986
;
Fromont et al. 2005
) and were included in the comparison.
C. celata
itself was considered, even though it has occasionally been observed with an additional spicule type , with raphides. Only
C. celata
without raphides is used for comparison, and it has been discussed that specimens with and without raphides belong to different species (e.g.
Rosell & Uriz 2002
). Some other species were not considered, because the original descriptions were insufficient and revised descriptions were unavailable (
Tab. 3
). Two other species were not included, although they only contain tylostyles and other authors described them as
Cliona
, but their status as bioeroders is unconfirmed (
Tab. 3
). All the above species are dissimilar to our present specimens or are invalid. Details for taxonomic decisions are given below.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Cliona minuscula
,
sp. nov.
morphological characters of QM G322595. A—Sample QM G322595 is a shell of
Tridacna crocea
, in which
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
and three other species of bioeroding sponges were found.
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
inhabits over 1/3 of the shell (area underneath white line). The left half is dominated by
Cliona cf. orientalis
. B—Inner surface of the shell and fracture surfaces.
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
does not penetrate the entire shell, except for a small area at the extreme opposite of the umbo, where the sponge forms a net­like pattern on the inside of the shell (near the zero of the cm scale). The white ellipse encloses macroscopic erosion traces of
Cliona ensifera
, the black ellipse
C. cf. orientalis
, the arrow points to chambers of
Aka
sp. C–D—Closer views of papillae of
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
, which are discrete, minute and evenly distributed. They have created pits in the substrate, resulting in their position being lower than the substrate surface (scale bars 1 cm and 1 mm, respectively). E–F—Erosion chambers of
Cliona minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(upper halves of figures, large chambers in lower halves of figures are occupied by
Aka
sp.; scale bars 1 mm). G–H—Pluck preparations of tissue (scales 100 µm). G—Loose tylostyle palisade of the ectosome. H—Ectosome with symbiotic dinoflagellates (arrow).

TABLE 1.
Cliona minuscula
,
sp. nov.
tylostyle dimensions in µm (N = 50 per specimen). Preparations contained ectosomal and endosomal spicules.

subSubSection.paragraph: Sample Dimension Minimum Mean Maximum SD

Remarks on
Cliona minuscula
,
sp. nov.

C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
was distinguished from 15 other clionaid species containing only tylostyles by using available original descriptions and additional references as listed (
Tab. 2
). The 15 comparison species were grouped based on the similarities of their taxonomic characters. The same grouping and sequence was retained in
Table 2
and
Figure 4
.

C. arenosa , C. californiana , C. celata
,
C. delitrix , C. dissimilis
and
C. laticavicola
are yellow to orange and have significantly longer tylostyles than
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
( 50–100 µm longer;
Fig. 4
A–I). Elongate­oval tyles are usually terminal in
C. minuscula
. sp. nov. , and more spherical and often subterminal in the other six species.
C. celata
,
C. delitrix , C. dissimilis
and
C. laticavicola
have larger erosion chambers, papillar diameters of> 1 mm and larger papillar canals than in
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(
Tab. 2
).
C. californiana , C. celata
,
C. delitrix
and
C. dissimilis
can occur in encrusting growth form, and
C. californiana
and
C. celata
may have free­living growth stages, which to date is unknown for
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(
Tab. 2
). Furthermore,
C. laticavicola
has only been found in the Caribbean and the Atlantic, and
C. californiana
only in the Western Pacific. There is very little information available on
C. arenosa
, but some authors have remarked on its affinity to
C. celata
(e.g.
Topsent 1889
).
C. arenosa
has been described as a massive sponge occurring in the North Atlantic at Florida (
Schmidt 1870
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Cliona minuscula
,
sp. nov.
tylostyles of QM G322595. A–B—Tylostyles mostly have straight shafts and oval to drop­shaped tyles that are slightly longer than wide. C–D—Occasionally, tylostyles have more spherical tyles with distinct neck areas.

subSubSection.paragraph:
A species group encompassing
C. ecaudis , C. janitrix , C. kempi
and
C. macgeachii
has tylostyles that are shorter and wider than in
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(
Fig. 4
J–O).
C. ecaudis
has two size classes of tylostyles (
Topsent 1932
), whereas
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
has only one.
C. ecaudis
and
C. janitrix
have larger erosion chambers and papillar sizes than
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(
Tab. 2
).
C. kempi
and
C. macgeachii
have small erosion chambers and very small papillar sizes, similar to
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(
Tab. 2
), but can easily be distinguished from
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
by their ensiform tylostyles (
Fig. 4
N–O). Unlike
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
,
C. janitrix
has tylostyles with subterminal tyles or even stylar modifications, and its tylostyle points are often mucronate, telescoped or stepped (
Fig. 4
K–M). With the exception of
C. kempi
, in which the colour has not been described, all the above species differ in colour from
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(
Tab. 2
), and to date none of them has been reported from the Great Barrier Reef (
Tab. 2
).

Tylostyle lengths of
C. alderi , C. insidiosa
,
C. millepunctata
and
C. peponaca
resemble those of
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(between 180 and 245 µm;
Fig. 4
P–V), but the spicule shapes differ. Tylostyles are on average wider in
C. alderi , C. insidiosa
and
C. peponaca
than in
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(
Fig. 4
P–S and V), and more delicate and thinner in
C. millepunctata
(
Fig. 4
T–U). Due to seasonal spicule formation, spicule width may not be a reliable character (
Schönberg and Barthel
1997
and
1998
), but other spicule characters were found to differ as well.
C. alderi
and
C. peponaca
display significant tylar variability, with subterminal and displaced, spherical tyles and modifications to styles (
Fig. 4
P–Q and V). Tylostyle shafts are slightly curved in both species. Tyle shape in
C. insidiosa
is very characteristic (
Fig. 4
R–S; ‘heads distally flattened’,
Rützler and Stone 1986
), with an angular constriction in the neck region. In
C. millepunctata
, the tylostyle shaft is more curved than in
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
, and can be sinous (
Fig. 4
T–U). These characters are atypical for
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
C. alderi , C. insidiosa
and
C. millepunctata
may be brown like
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(only dried colours are known;
Tab. 2
), but they are likely to be European species (Hancock’s species are mostly from England ), which further reduces the chance of conspecifity with
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
C. peponaca
is a richly yellow Caribbean species and clearly distinct from
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
(
Tab. 2
).

C. caesia
shares a number of characters with
C. minuscula ,
sp. nov.
Both species have been sampled from the same site, have very small papillae and erosion chambers, are dark brown, contain symbiotic dinoflagellates, and have predominantly straight tylostyles (
Tab. 2
). However, in
C. caesia
tylostyles are longer on average, tyles are distinctly more spherical and often wider than long (
Fig. 4
W). Furthermore,
C. caesia
has two size classes of tylostyles and light blue rings on extended papillae (
Tab. 2
), which is not the case for
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.

. No images of
C. arenosa
were available. X–Z—Spicules of the other three species of bioeroding sponges found in sample QM G322595. X—
C. ensifera .
Y—
Aka
sp., Z—
C. cf. orientalis
. All spicules to scale, scale bar 100 µm.

TABLE 2. Comparison of taxonomic characters between
Cliona minuscula
,
sp. nov.
, 15 other clionaid sponges that have only tylostyles as their only skeletal elements, and the three other species of bioeroding sponges found in the holotype QM G322595. Tylostyle dimensions are means of length x shaft width x tyle width in µm, where data are available. For
Cliona ensifera
tylostyle dimensions of the neck region are given as well. Where multiple characters are given, they are aligned with their respective references in the last column.

For all the reasons listed above we conclude that
C. minuscula
is a new species. Together with the finding of
C. ensifera
in the same specimen as
C. minuscula
,
sp. nov.
, and with two previously unrecorded observations of
C. mucronata
and
C. schmidti
, the present study extends the number of species of the genus
Cliona
reported from Australia to 11 species, with 10 of them from the Great Barrier Reef (
Tab. 4
).

subSection.paragraph:
C. minuscula
is described here as a new species that only contains tylostyles. The entire species group of bioeroding sponges containing only tylostyles as spicules has been examined in this publication. We have listed invalid species names that were still occasionally used, compiled previously scattered information on the species, and reduced the number of species which need to be considered in studies such as this. The illustration of spicules drawn to comparable scale, and the table of species characters allow easy
Cliona infrafoliata Unlikely
to be an obligate bioeroding sponge, present publication

subSection.paragraph:
Thiele, 1898
incertae sedis. Thiele 1889 One of Thiele’s specimens of
C. infrafoliata
was coating plant material instead of calcium carbonate (‘Das eine Exemplar bildete einen ausgedehnten Überzug auf einem pflanzlichen Körper, das könnte vielleicht gegen eine solche Beziehung zu einem Bohrschwamm sprechen.’).
to be continued.

Cliona neptuni Invalid
species: synonymous with
C. patera .
Annandale 1915 b

Cliona patera C. patera
is the Neptune’s Cup, which has
Annandale 1915 b
The examined sample MHNG 38767 from the present publication Museum in Geneva is a dried section of a freeliving sponge. No fragments were found in the tissues, and the base was cut off so that the
bioeroding status could not be confirmed. Only tylostyles were found, which were extremely sizevariable. The sponge was morphologically very structured with firm cortical regions and an
endosome with large pore spaces that were

traversed by fibres formed by tylostyle bundles. All observed characters distinguish this sponge from
C. minuscula
sp. nov.
As osculae were evenly

distributed, we decided against placing it into the genus
Spheciospongia
. As it represented a fully massive sponge, we also rejected the genus

Spirastrella
. Following
Topsent ( 1909 )
, we placed it tentatively into the genus
Cliona
, incertae sedis.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 4. Species of the genus
Cliona
recorded from Australia (in alphabetical order). Not all species listed here belong in the species complex with only tylostyles, therefore basic taxonomic features are listed in the last column. There are 6 further species of bioeroding sponges from Australia that were formerly included in the genus
Cliona
, but are now considered to belong to different genera:
Cliothosa lesueuri (Topsent, 1888)
,
Pione carpenteri (Hancock, 1867)
,
Pione lutea
(von Lendenfeld, 1888),
Pione vastifica (Hancock, 1849)
,
Pione velans (Hentschel, 1909)
and
Spheciospongia hixoni
(von Lendenfeld, 1886).

subSection.paragraph: to be continued ..... The authors would like to thank staff at the Orpheus Island Research Station and W. Loh for assistance during fieldwork. We are grateful for access to the SEM unit at the Queensland Museum, Brisbane, Australia and acknowledge the kind assistance by S. List­ Armitage and J. Hooper. T. Cribb provided access to a light microscope with camera lucida. R. Desqueyroux­Faundez sent us the loan of MHNG 38767 . A. Lawton, W. Loh, J. Davy, T. Ridgway and three anonymous reviewers commented on the manuscript style and language. During the time of fieldwork, the first author was supported by The Alexander von Humboldt Foundation, Bonn, Germany , by the Centre for Marine Studies and funding to O. Hoegh­Guldberg (Australian Research Council). Furthermore, we would like to acknowledge donations to The University of Queensland Chancellor’s Fund 2004 to support research on bioeroding sponges, which were partly used to cover expenses for the present study.
